title: CIPS Analysis Report - Fall 2024
text:
Preface
This report presents a comprehensive analysis of data collected on STEM instructional practices during the Fall 2024 semester. The aim is to provide insights into the effectiveness of various teaching methods and strategies employed in STEM education. Through detailed statistical analyses and visualizations, this report seeks to inform educators, policymakers, and researchers about the current state of STEM instruction and identify areas for improvement.
You can select a relevant section to explore to the left. Then, you will see a table of contexts to the right that you can explore further.

title: 1  Methods
text:
1.1 Participants by course
There were 3697 unique students across 49 course/groups with 23 instructors participating.

title: 2  Overview of Practices
text:
occurrence Percent of students reporting the practice occurred
impact_rating Mean rating (1-5) of how impactful the practice was IF they said practice occurred
high_impact Percent of students who put the practice was “Extremely Important” (5 of 5)
frequency_more_than_1_per_month Percent of the practice being frequent (“About 2-3 times per month” or “At least 1 time per week”)
occurrence_this_week Percent of students reporting it had occurred in the past week.
occurrence_inst_report Percent of instructors reporting “Yes”
occurence_inst_NO Percent of students reporting (if instructor “No”) -
occurence_inst_YES Percent of students reporting (if instructor “Yes”) -
occurence_inst_signal Difference in student reporting when instructor says YES or NO
ICC Intraclass Correlation Coefficient

title: 2  Overview of Practices
text:
2.3 Ranking items
We also sort based on what makes a “good” item. I used the following criteria as a first pass: - students find impactful Do students find the practice impactful? (<25th %ile = 0 point; 25th-75th %ile = 1 points, 75-90%ile = 2 points; >90%ile = 3 points)  - Is it significantly more important to marginalized students? (No = 0 points; Yes = 2 points) - is there consistency of student-reports within courses? (<25th %ile = 0 point; 25th-75th %ile = 1 points, >75%ile = 2 points) - is there a signal across courses? (non-significant F-value = 0 point; <75%ile sig F-value = 1 point, >75%ile = 2 points) - does it predict student experiences? - students want instructors to prioritize (NEED TO ADD IN IMPORTANCE) - signal by instructor Are there positive differences in student reports when instructors do or do not report a practice? (<= 0 difference = -1 points; 0-.10 = 0 points; .10-.20 = 1 point; .20-.30 = 2 points; .30-.40 = 4 points; etc.) - In what percent of courses is there significant change?* p<.05 and shift of > 10% in student responses. ( Determine criteria)

title: 4  Grouping practices together
text:
4.1 Eric’s grouping
There are a few ways we might consider grouping practices together. Below we present some of these ways:

title: 4  Grouping practices together
text:
4.1.1 Correlation matrix of unordered practices
Below, you’ll see some evidence that those items within the same group are more highly correlated. However, this could be an artifact of those items being presented on the same page to reduce student cognitive load.
You can zoom in on the graph below, or double-click to zoom out. On hover, you can see the pearson correlation between practice reporting.

text:
5.1 Students’ descriptions of courses
Below you can find open-responses collected from instructors and students. Data has been limited to 1000 rows to reduce load on your browser.
You can click on the blue buttons below to see and search the responses.
Other than the things you’ve already shared, is there anything else you do in your course that you think other instructors would be interested in? (e.g., something new you are trying, something you are proud of, etc.). If so, please describe below.

title: 6  Codebook
text:
Below is the survey codebooks
Below you will find relevant information about all variables in the datafiles:

source = Where did the column come from?
var_category = What category of data is it?

ID = identifiers
Survey Data = information about survey engagement and completion
Condition = manipulated conditions
Demographics = unique data linked to participant
Demographics (Calculated) = unique data linked to participant; calculated or aggregate
Course Experience = Quantitative data on overall course experiences
Personal Beliefs = Quantitative data on general experiences
Practices = The practices collected

var_type = What type of data is it?
var_original_name = The original variable name in cleaning files
var_original_name = The updated variable name in cleaning files
var_intro_wording (optional) = Wording provided to participant prior to completing the item
var_wording = Item wording provided to participant OR description of calculated variable
var_scale = Response scale information
var_notes (optional) = Any other relevant information about the variable
var_reference (unused at this time) = TBD

You can search using the search button in the top right. Example search terms:

“logical” = find all binary T/F variables
“Demographics” = find all demographic items collected
“A14” = find all variables that start with A14
